newsitem.title: FRANCE: Juppe says no French unilateral move in Zaire.
newsitem.headline: Juppe says no French unilateral move in Zaire.

text.p: Prime Minister Alain Juppe ruled out on Saturday a unilateral French military intervention in Zaire where rebels are increasingly threatening the government, which is allied to Paris.

"We do not intend to launch again a solely French operation and, after all, we do not have all the means to carry it out either," he told Canal-Plus television. France has been pressing in recent days for a multinational peace force to be sent to Zaire.

Juppe said France still hoped for the creation of such a force whose aim would be to establish security areas where humanitarian aid could be distributed. "France cannot do everything by itself, be it in Zaire or in Albania," said Juppe.
He said Paris backed United Nations efforts to bring about a cease-fire and the departure of foreign troops from Zaire.

France has long propped up Zairean president Mobutu Sese Seko. Its most notable intervention was in 1977 when it sent hundreds of foreign legion paratroopers to retake Kolwezi, capital of mineral-rich Shaba province, which had been invaded by Cuban-trained rebels.

The United States, now squabbling with Paris over policy towards Zaire, then supplied the aircraft which airlifted the legionnaires from Corsica to Zaire for a dramatic jump over Kolwezi where rebels were starting to kill foreign civilians.
